results.title: Queensland
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Holiday”.
Beginning with Brisbane’s elegant houses, this Queensland travel video also moves inland and along the expansive coastline. Enjoy the recreational activities on Hamilton Island, join a backpack tour that includes scuba diving, bush walking and horse riding, experience the Stockman’s Hall of Fame and the waterhole which inspired the Waltzing Matilda legend, visit the beaches of Surfer’s Paradise and Noosa, kayak in the Daintree Forest or sail to tranquil locations in the Whitsuday Islands.

results.title: A New vision
results.creator_credit: John Halas and Halas and Batchelor Cartoon Films
results.brief_description: A short series of films about great artists which aims to entertain and excite audience attention as well as to inform, by blending computer animation and graphics, traditional animation and, where appropriate, live action with shots of the works under discussion.

results.title: Backstroke, breaststroke, butterfly, freestyle
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Swimming with Mark Tonelli”.
A compilation tape containing five programmes designed to instruct on swimming techniques. 1.Backstroke. Demonstrated by Commonwealth Gold Medallist Mark Tonelli. 2.Breaststroke. Demonstrated by British Gold Medallist Duncan Tonelli. 3.Butterfly. Demonstrated by Mark Tonelli. 4. Freestyle. Demonstrated by Mark Tonelli. 5.Starts and Turns. Demonstrated by Mark Tonelli and Drew Mayhew.

results.title: Swimming
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Swimming with Mark Tonelli”.
Approved by the Department of Education, this video is designed for swimming instruction. Mark Tonelli and Duncan Goodhew, both Olympic gold medallists, give instruction on freestyle, breaststroke, backstroke, butterfly and the mechanics of swimming. Each stroke is treated as a separate entity. Teacher’s notes are also available.

results.title: Battle for the land. Parts 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: Ian McFarlane, Chris Bryer and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Politics of food”.
These episodes in the “Politics of Food” series examine poverty and hunger in Brazil. Brazil is one of the world leaders in food exports yet 1 in 8 children in poor areas will die from malnutrition. Much of the land which could be used to produce food crops is given over to high yield export crops such as sugar and cocoa. With little land to grow food many of the rural population have migrated to the cities where urban poverty is rife. As a consequence, corruption and violence are evident as the battle between wealthy landowners and the impoverished continues.

results.title: The Hunger machine. Parts 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: Ian McFarlane, Chris Bryer and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Politics of food”.
Feeding the hungry of the world is not just an exercise in good agricultural practices or a result of foreign aid and trade. Governments can affect farmers by imposing tarrifs or providing subsidies so that even in times of surplus, the needy may be disadvantaged. More productive agricultural programmes can increase food supply, however in developing countries who receive aid and food, the incentive to develop these practices may not be encouraged by the political forces in power.

results.title: The Aid trap. Parts 1 & 2
results.creator_credit: Chris Bryer, Derek Jones, Judith Weymont and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Politics of food”.
Wealthy western nations in more recent times, have given aid to poorer nations struck by disasters such as famine, flood and war. The primary purpose of aid is to strengthen a political relationship between allies. Both parts of the video compare situations in Kerala and Bangladesh in terms of food distibution and programmes to prevent problems caused by overpopulation. At the time of production, food distribution in Bangladesh was hampered by corrupt political infra-structures in some areas, while education was not a high priority. In Kerala the effects of sound educational programmes and a fairer distribution of resources was examined.

results.title: Everybody's business: management in action (NP)
results.creator_credit: Mark Davis, Open Learning Agency of Australia, Monash University and ABC-TV (Australia)
results.brief_description: Today the workplace is changing. Quantum changes in the world economy, in technology and in society itself have brought about a revolution in the nature of work. Increasing use of self-management strategies have led to a far greater sharing of management functions through the whole workforce. The classic functions of management - planning, organising, leading, and controlling are becoming everybody’s business, hence the title of this series. Throughout the series, reporter Cheryl Hall explores the new approaches to management in all sectors of the workforce. Kerry O’Brien speaks to experts on the key issues of management today.
